fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • In a piece about the role of private philanthropy at a time when cultural institutions are facing state cuts, the focus was on a reported £25m donation by Lord [John] Sainsbury for a new wing at the British Museum. The museum has sent a clarification saying that the £25m actually comprises £12.5m from Lord Sainsbury's Linbury Trust to be paid over the next three years, and £12.5m from the Monument Trust established by John Sainsbury's late brother Simon (Be more like Sainsbury, UK rich urged, 13 September, page 9). • Readers were surprised when a quote had the author of Delusions of Gender, Cordelia Fine, seemingly saying: "These cultural lores [about male and female brains and minds]… are standing in the way of greater sex inequality." That was meant to be "equality" (Men are from Mars, women are from… Mars too? 11 September, page 3). • We were off beam in describing the Leslie Howard film 'Pimpernel' Smith as a tribute to Spitfire pilots. The homage to the Spitfire and its designer RJ Mitchell was The First of the Few (Reels show 1930s actor in a new light, 13 September, page 13). • Our review of the final episode of ITV's Heartbeat said that we never find out if Alf, having been impaled on a pitchfork, pulls through. It was Oscar who fell foul of the agricultural implement (The weekend's TV, 13 September, page 25, G2). • We described Stephen Green, HSBC's chairman, as a lay minister. Rather, he is an ordained Anglican priest (HSBC man Green chosen as trade minister after four-month search, 8 September, page 13).
